visual_content: A promotional banner for 'ElectroCharge' offering savings. It displays a dark-colored modern electric SUV next to a charging station. The text includes 'UNLOCK HUGE SAVINGS', 'GET 30% OFF ALL CHARGES THIS MONTH', 'Limited-time offer for ElectroCharge members.', and a promo code 'CHARGE30' with an 'APPLY NOW' button. A generic barcode strip is present at the bottom.
anomalies: No strong visual anomalies directly indicative of a cyberattack. The 30% discount, while substantial, is presented as a 'limited-time offer for ElectroCharge members,' which makes it a plausible marketing strategy. The images appear to be standard stock photography or well-integrated visuals, not obviously deepfake or AI-generated in a malicious context. The branding 'ElectroCharge' is consistent within the promotion. The barcode, like in Kiosk 2, appears generic but isn't a direct sign of a cyberattack.

visual_content: A stylized yellow icon resembling a coupon or ticket (depicting two horizontal lines on the left and two small circles on the right), accompanied by the text 'No Active Promotions'.
anomalies: None. The interface explicitly states 'No Active Promotions' and the visual icon is generic, not suggesting any misleading offers or suspicious content.

visual_content: The promotion area displays a rectangular graphic with 'ElectroCharge' branding at the top. It advertises 'UNLOCK HUGE SAVINGS GET 30% OFF ALL CHARGES THIS MONTH' with a disclaimer 'Limited-time offer for ElectroCharge members.' An image of a silver electric SUV/crossover is shown connected to a charging station. The text 'CHARGE30' is visible along with an 'APPLY NOW' button and a barcode-like graphic. A prominent yellow banner above the promotion explicitly states 'Special 10% Discount Available!'.
anomalies: The primary anomaly is the significant inconsistency in the advertised discount. The yellow banner explicitly states 'Special 10% Discount Available!', while the promotion graphic itself advertises 'GET 30% OFF ALL CHARGES THIS MONTH'. This large discrepancy (10% vs 30%) is a common red flag in phishing attempts or scams, designed to confuse users and potentially lure them with an overly generous, yet inconsistent, offer. The 'APPLY NOW' button could also be a vector for phishing if it directs users to a malicious external site.
